entry.title: DNS tracking & identification
entry.summary: How can you be tracked around using stateless web and a few DNS queries
entry.content:
Context

I work in the advertising field. Months ago, I heard about DNS Cookies but did not believe that one can actually track people using it. I was wrong

So we had that website, dnscookie.com hitting the top on hackernews.

Eventually, in the advertising field, a lot of people asked themselves about it. dnscookie.com explains basically how we can track users using DNS Cookies, but (IMHO) is not very precise.

I decided to take a look on my spare time and publish everything I learnt.

In my own point of view, explaining this method to "everyone" is a way to prevent abuses from avertising companies.

I'll use the term "DNS tracking" instead of DNS Cookie, to avoid confusion with RFC 7873

General Explanation

There is two important things involved in order to track users using DNS.

  • RFC 7873: DNS Cookies. It allows "grouping" DNS Queries and answers per clients, at server side, by doing, eg, log UDP network analysis.
  • HTTP has to be used at some point. Individual HTTP Queries have to be correlated with DNS activity, especially when the DNS cache is hit

The general method can be explained in 4 steps, with 4 prerequesites.

  • You own and control the authoritative DNS Server involved
  • Same for HTTP Servers
  • You have to hack both to emit various events in real time, ie, DNS resolutions and HTTP GET queries
  • You have to be able to correlate events emited by those below, in pseudo-realtime

Steps:

  • (1): Force a client to perform DNS resolutions on various subdomains subsequently followed by HTTP queries.
    This is achieved by including statics within a webpage, like images or even fonts (using CSS for tracking? Who cares).

  • (2): Extract DNS resolutions performed by a single client (identifiable using the DNS Cookie) in step (1).
    Those could be missing if the client is already known (== DNS answer still in client's cache).

  • (3): HTTP requests are fired by the browser to fetch statics, on domains previously resolved in (1) or stored in DNS cache.
    Considering 2 backend HTTP Servers and 32 HTTP queries distributed (randomly) on both, this creates or recreates
    a 32 bits identifier.

  • (4): as every resouce queried in HTTP is uniquely identifiable, correlating batches of 32 queries on multiple backend servers allow us to forge a somewhat reliable identifier.
    If the client is already known, the step (1) and (2) are skipped, because DNS answers are still in the client's cache, and the distribution on backends HTTP server will be the same. Leading to the same identifier.

It's somewhat important to avoid any browser-based caching at step (3). This is prevented by using unique URLs, as the initial index.html (or whatever includes our 32 statics inclusion) is generated on-the-fly for each HTTP query.

Sequence Diagram

example.com has IP 10.10.0.1

Two IP are used to determine/forge an identifier, 10.10.1.1 and 10.10.1.2

Efficiencies

I was able to track myself, even while switching to private navigation, with a high rate of success. (from my own poc, failures were essentially due to errors/imprecisions in my code)

It's like the same DNS cache is shared in major web browsers, even when private navigation is used. I'll be happy if someone could confirm/infirm this.

From an advertiser point of view, this could complete a more traditionnal cookie-based approach.

Possible inefficiencies

Cache control

Due to the recursive nature of the DNS, multiple levels of caching could be an issue.

Shared cache

If the cache is shared against many clients, It become hard to track a single user.

This kind of setup is common within entreprise-grade networks. This could eventually be tricked by using a large number of sudomains, or dynamic subdomains using unique identifiers.

At this point, a large and frequent load of DNS resolutions using high domain entropy could trigger some intrusion detection systems.

Reaction from vendors

I don't know the major web-browser positions on this topic. From my (naive) perspective, Countermeasures could be easily implemented client-side, eg, by ignoring supplied DNS cookies.

Available Countermeasures

I don't know any simple trick to avoid this tracking. If it's well implemented, it's pretty efficient. Once again, if someone has an idea, let me know.

My point of view

The traditionnal use of HTTP Cookies for tracking purpose is already somewhat an abuse.

DNS tracking abuses a different level, the DNS Protocol and DNS-Cookies. It's similar to a de-anonymisation attack. Cache is abused and logs from two differents protocols (DNS/HTTP) are correlated.

Considering the GDPR, the DNS cookie could be considered as something that permits unique identification.

Anyway, it's hard to believe that the "online advertising world" is trying to help consumers using such ... nasty tricks?

I'd better bet on privacy to regain consumers trust, then try to disrupt how preferences and behavior are used, to offer more control to the end-user and a less invasive approach. But that's way too utopic because ... nobody likes ads?

entry.title: Fork+Exec
entry.summary: Hot Reloading network-related code using syscalls older than me
entry.content:
Hot Reloading

Any HTTP Server have to setup and bind a socket to any available port. This is basically how any kind of server work. Even in IPv6. Even within a blockchainğŸ˜‚!

At some point, you'll have to restart them. Depending on the task (code deployment, configuration deployment, server update), the process (at OS level) may need to stop and start again. During this process, the main listening socket (usually bound on port 80 or 443 in the simplest configuration) could eventually "disconnect" and let your clients hitting a dry wall, leading to service discontinuation - and often, we (IT people) don't like that very much.

At my previous job, I wondered how uWSGI (which is itself a kind of HTTP Server with tons of features) performs its "hot-reload", without "un-binding" it's main socket. Yep. It does that. Without crashing clients. At all!

Let's be clear - we don't talk about automatic recompilation when the code changes - but delivering consistent HTTP responses for a thousand of motherfuckers per seconds while upgrading business critical software!

Other approach

In modern configurations, we often relies on load-balancers during rolling updates, because a few nodes may eventually be unavailable during the reload operation.

In an other hand, essentially in functionnal languages (but can be also done in Java), you can "update" the runtime while it's running. This is the case with Clojure and Erlang, both respectively relying on the JVM and BEAM. Because of the emphasis on purity (lack of side effects, globals, vars, etc), one can update a function's code without worrying breaking everything down.

But still - that's a lot of constrains. What about a "real" OS Process level hot reloading?

At process (Linux) level

Returning to the uWSGI example from above

When you deploy a new configuration or new code, you basically ask uWSGI to reload and, "magic happens". You'll see uWSGI lying around with a brand new PID, but the listening socket is still there - still listening without interruption.

No high-level trick nor load-balancing are needed - Linux can fucking handle this if your code is smart enough :) You can even restore client's states - which is awesome for long polling connection.

Lazy version

Using SO_REUSEADDR and SO_REUSEPORT, one can bind more than one socket (from one or more processes) on a given couple (IP, PORT). We can achieve a somewhat "grateful reloading" with these:

main_socket.setsockopt(socket.SOL_SOCKET, socket.SO_REUSEADDR, 1)
main_socket.setsockopt(socket.SOL_SOCKET, socket.SO_REUSEPORT, 1)

and start a parallel, updated process, while asking the oldest and deprecated to stop accepting new clients. But still ... this implies a new socket somewhere. Also, it implies a recent Linux Kernel.

Fork+exec

Explanation:

These are a few prerequisites:

  • Sockets should be configured without the flag SOCK_CLOEXEC. Else, all opened filedescriptors will automatically close at exec call.
  • main socket's bind operation should only be done once - after the initial creation. While reloading, this socket is never recreated - but instead duplicated from a fileno passed as argument to the program itself.
  • fcntl(server_socket, fcntl.F_SETFD, socket.SOCK_CLOEXEC) looks always mandatory, even after a reload. I can't explain this right know.

Commented code (python3):

This example leverage the fork+exec mechanism using Python and its standard library. It stays easy to read (and easier/faster to write than C equivalent)

I kept it very simple - this server can't handle concurrent clients, and that's okay. 

#!/bin/env python3
import os
import fcntl
import socket
import signal
import argparse

# fork + exec python server example

server_socket = None
client_sockets = []


def client_processing(sock):
    '''
    Hello Worldâ„¢ for the socket programming world
    '''
    while True:
        ct = sock.recv(4096)
        if b'hello' in ct:
            sock.send(b"... world!")
            break
    sock.close()



def reload_now(*args):
    '''
    asynchronously called by a signal
    (here, SIGUSR1)
    '''
    pid = os.fork()

    if pid == 0:
        # child
        client_filenos = [str(i.fileno()) for i in client_sockets]        
        print(f"child: main.py {server_socket.fileno()} {' '.join(client_filenos)}")
        os.execvp(__file__, [__file__, str(server_socket.fileno()), *[str(i) for i in client_filenos]])
    elif pid != -1:
        # parent's exit
        # achieve a daemon
        print('parent is exiting')
        exit(0)
    else:
        print('os.fork failed :(')
        exit(1)



def start(server_fileno, clients_fileno):
    '''
    Server entry point.
    This function can be called in two different ways:

    (None, []) -> setup a classic listening socket
    (filedescriptor: str, clients_fileno: List[str]) -> "re" bind the listening socket
    then continue to serve previously accepted clients
    '''
    print(f'\n...START\n  {server_fileno}, {clients_fileno} ' )
    global server_socket
    global client_sockets
    signal.signal(signal.SIGUSR1, reload_now)

    if server_fileno:
        # open "inherited" socket
        server_socket = socket.fromfd(int(server_fileno), socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)
        # We have to call fcnt again, dunno really why.
        # If not, we can only reload once, which is stupid
        fcntl.fcntl(server_socket, fcntl.F_SETFD, socket.SOCK_CLOEXEC)
    else:
        # create socket
        server_socket = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)
        fcntl.fcntl(server_socket, fcntl.F_SETFD, socket.SOCK_CLOEXEC)
        # set main socket options
        server_socket.setsockopt(socket.SOL_SOCKET, socket.SO_REUSEADDR, 1)
        server_socket.setsockopt(socket.SOL_SOCKET, socket.SO_REUSEPORT, 1)

        server_socket.bind(('localhost', 8000))

    server_socket.listen(10)

    # if we came from a reload,
    # serve previous before accessing main loop below
    # (in real life, these will be delayed to asynchronous tasks or dedicated threads, instead of
    # blocking right here - but you get the idea)
    if len(clients_fileno):
        print('resuming clients...')
        for fd in clients_fileno:
            s = socket.fromfd(int(fd), socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)
            client_sockets.append(s)
            client_processing(s)
            client_sockets.remove(s)


    # "Accept" loop
    # This is our main loop
    while True:
        (client_socket, (client_addr, client_port)) = server_socket.accept()

        # This step is important
        # We don't want this client owned socket to close itself after an `exec` system call.
        fcntl.fcntl(client_socket, fcntl.F_SETFD, socket.SOCK_CLOEXEC)
        print("new client @{}:{}".format(client_addr, client_port))

        # We trick using a global here. Also, in real life,
        # the "processing" part have to be asynchronous, or delayed
        # into some worker processes (or both!).
        # 
        # Here, we handle clients sequentially and individually for the sake of
        # clarity and understanding
        client_sockets.append(client_socket)
        client_processing(client_socket)
        client_sockets.remove(client_socket)
        print(f"client {client_addr}:{client_port} disconnected")


def main():
    '''
    '''
    print(f'[*] Running\n[*] host: localhost, port: 8000,  pid: {os.getpid()}')
    print(f'executes `kill -s SIGUSR1 {os.getpid()}` in a shell to trigger a "live-reload"')
    print(f'executes `nc localhost 8000` to establish a connection')
    print('The server waits for the input "hello", then answers and closes the connection.')

    p = argparse.ArgumentParser(prog='Fork+exec python example')
    p.add_argument('filedescriptors', nargs='*')
    args = p.parse_args()

    print(args)
    import sys
    print(sys.argv)
    if len(args.filedescriptors):
        # hot reload case
        start(args.filedescriptors[0], args.filedescriptors[1:])
    else:
        start(None, [])


if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

More ressources on the subject:

  • uWSGI - The art of Graceful Reloading
  • Hot reloading in Clojure code
  • File Descriptor Flags (FD_CLOEXEC used as fcntl argument)
  • Forkexec on wikipedia
  • socket - GNU MAN
  • Python's documentation about socket.fromfd

Three weeks ago, I ran across some strange publications on facebook, originating from various friends.

Looking at the domain - s3.amazonaws.com - and the spreading all around my facebook friends - I decided to dig - furthermore.

TL;DR

Facebook's share abuse:

A combination of dirty tricks, like CSS opacity and iframe inception, allowed to force an arbitrary user to share some content with its own facebook account - to anyone visiting a website controlled by the attacker.

Since the malicious action was to "share" the malicious website, the thing quickly started to spread.

entry.title: Persistent Archlinux USB key
entry.summary: Archlinux with encrypted root partition, on a USB key, from an existing Linux, with EFI. Sounds funny right?
entry.content:
note: This was written in a hurry.

Intro:

Setup a persistent archlinux on a USB key, with encrypted root partition, from an existing Linux (Gentoo in my case, but you should be able to do this from various Linux distros).

I've essentially followed two articles from the excellent archlinux wiki:

  • Install frome existing Linux
  • https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Installing_Arch_Linux_on_a_USB_key

Also,

  • https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Dm-crypt/System_configuration#Boot_loader
  • https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/Installation_guide

could be useful.

I'll try my best to explain what I've added/changed to use a LUKs container for my root partition.

Big picture

  1. UEFI boots: bootx64.efi

  2. /boot/EFI/BOOT/bootx64.efi is generated by grub-mkimage using /boot/grub/grub.cfg

  3. initramfs starts

  4. It prepares the filesystem and load early drivers. Usually, I don't use an initramfs, but LUKs is so easy to setup using mkinitcpio and an initrd (initial ramdisk).

  5. Decrypt our root partition before giving control to the kernel

  6. Kernel boots

  7. Login shell

1 - Preparation

I need an UEFI setup, since every laptop I use works with UEFI.

To achieve this, I've made two partitions (keep it simple), The first, approx. 200mb for booting purposes, of type GPT and formated using FAT32. The rest, for our encrypted Archlinux system. Using a non-journalised EXT4 filesystem inside a LUKs partition.

I'll explain this later in this blog post.

2 - Setup the USB key

  • One GPT partition to host EFI binaries. I used parted to do that.
  • The rest is up to you. I used the whole space left on the device.

You should format the GPT partition to FAT32, using something like:

mkfs.fat -F32 /dev/sdxX

My second partition is a LUKS encrypted partition.

From the luks tutorial, merged with some advice from Installing Arch on a USB key:

$ cryptsetup -y -v luksFormat --type luks2 /dev/sdaX  ## your root partition on the usb key
$ cryptsetup open /dev/sdaX cryptroot
$ mkfs.ext4 -O "^has_journal" /dev/mapper/cryptroot

Disabling journal reduce the number of IO operations. But, be careful to always properly umount the partition before unplugging your device. Otherwise, data will be lost.

3 - Install archlinux

Okay. Archlinux installation, even from a random Linux distribution is pretty straightforward.

Be sure to correctly mount your root partition using LUKs, and every other needed partition (/boot in my example)

root $ cryptsetup open /dev/sdXX cryptroot
root $ mount /dev/mapper/cryptroot /mnt

Following the Archlinux wiki (Install_from_existing_Linux), the first step is to grab a bootstrap image (minimal archlinux system). Decompress it directly into /mnt, then mount the _boot partitionÂ  with mount /dev/sdXY /mnt/boot.

Now, you can chroot into /mnt (with /mnt/bin/arch-root /mnt), initialize pacman keyring, prepare the base system and configure locales.

4 Generate initial ramdisk

The inistal ramdisk is an essential thing, since we use an encrypted root partition. We've got a few HOOKS to add into /etc/mkinitcpio.conf. According to the doc:

Before creating the initial RAM disk # mkinitcpio -p linux, in /etc/mkinitcpio.conf add the block hook to the hooks array right after udev. This is necessary for appropriate module loading in early userspace.

Then, generated everything with : mkinitcpio -p Linux. This is why you have to mount your /boot partition before this operation.

5 - Boot related shit

Intro - how stuff will work:

The main goal in this section is to generate a valid grub image, contained into an efi binary. This executable could be later found by the most of EFI-bios, either in a manual or automatic way.

The executable is located under /boot/EFI/BOOT/bootx64.efi. I had to do this to get it working. It may be different for your contructor, do not hesitate to googe " efi executable location"

I found this technique more simple and more flexible (I can use multiple kernels, avoid EFI_STUB), also less scary (I don't touch to efivars ;)).

note about fstab

We won't need to include /, the root filesystem, in our fstab, since the kernel will decrypt and mount it (and this is why we'll manage to pass additional paramaters to the kernel in the next section).

Creating basic grub configuration

Since we have just generated our initramfs (using mkinitcpio) and a kernel may have been installed into /boot, grub-mkconfig should detect everything (the kernel is usually named vmlinuz-linux)

Be carefull to run grub-mkconfig into your chrooted environment, with all filesystems (/boot and / in our case) properly mounted.

(chroot) $ grub-mkconfig -o /boot/grub/grub.cfg

Editing basic grub configuration

Remenber to add these kernel parameters, they are mandatory in order to decrypt your filesystem:

  • cryptdevice=UUID=<your device UUID>:cryptroot You can get your device's UUID with the blkid command.

  • root=/dev/mapper/cryptroot cryptroot is an alias. If you decide to change it, do it also for the cryptdevice parameter above.

$ grub-mkimage   -c /boot/EFI/BOOT/grub.cfg \
                 -d /usr/lib/grub/x86_64-efi \
                 -o /boot/EFI/BOOT/bootx64.efi \
                 -p /efi/boot \
                 -O x86_64-efi \
                 fat iso9660 part_gpt part_msdos normal boot linux configfile loopback chain \
                 efifwsetup efi_gop efi_uga ls search search_label search_fs_uuid \
                 search_fs_file gfxterm gfxterm_background

Meanwhile, here's /boot/EFI/BOOT/grub.cfg's content:

configfile /grub/grub.cfg

were /grub/grub.cfg designates /boot/grub/grub.cfg, previously generated by grub-mkconfig and edited to properly decrypt our root partition.

End

I had to reboot several times to see a login shell :').

Doing this was funny - and could eventually be useful. Be sure to use a decent USB key, because IO performance is a little low. It is also pretty secure (thanks LUKS), but you still have to trust the hardware and low level components.

PS

I don't have any performant device, so starting a program is always slow. I use this USB key as a safe storage device, for both backup purposes and emergency linux distro.

Dans la seconde partie, j'illustrerai call/cc avec Scheme, cette fonctionnalitÃ© n'Ã©tant pas prÃ©sente dans Clojure.

  • On commence avec les appels de fonctions (Ã  la base des lisp) :
  (func 1 "string")

L'Ã©quivalent en Python :

Les lisps sont composÃ©s de s-expressions. (+ 1 10) en est une, tout comme nos dÃ©finitions de fonctions plus haut. Pour retourner une valeur, il faut quelle soit Ã©valuÃ©e en dernier dans une fonction.

Ok, normalement vous avez Ã©galement saisi comment on commente (avec ';'). Maintenant que vous vous Ãªtes echauffÃ©s, regardons du code en Clojure, vs le mÃªme mais dans un Scheme plus "traditionnel"

N'hÃ©sitez pas Ã  vous intÃ©resser davantage aux Lisps si vous pataugez avant d'attaquer la suite de cet article. call/cc est assez mindfuck au dÃ©but, malgrÃ© l'Ã©tonnante simplicitÃ© des principes rÃ©gissant ces langages.

Pour aller un peu plus loin sur la partie Lisp, je vous conseille BraveClojure. Pour Scheme (et donc call/cc et dÃ©rivÃ©s), il existe pas mal d'implÃ©mentations. Dans ses spÃ©cifications, Scheme dÃ©crit les continuations comme des objets/citoyens de premiÃ¨re classe (on peut assigner des continuation Ã  des variables, les stocker dans des listes, ...).

ConcrÃ¨tement, la continuation se matÃ©rialise sous la forme une fonction. Si on l'appelle, on "bifurque" dans la logique d'execution d'un programme. (On peut aussi dire "dÃ©router"). Pensez setjmp et longjmp en C, si Ã§a vous parle.

Revenons Ã  call/cc ! call-with-current-continuation permet d'appeler une fonction en lui passant la continuation actuelle en paramÃ¨tre. Si la fonction appelÃ©e appelle la continuation, call-with-current-continuation retourne l'argument (peu importe) passÃ© Ã  la continuation.

;; display permet d'afficher du texte sur 
;; la sortie standard
(display (call-with-current-continuation func))

J'ai dis plus haut que "la valeur retournÃ©e par une fonction en lisp est la valeur de la derniÃ¨re expression Ã©valuÃ©". Et bien, pas forcÃ©ment. Avec call/cc, on peut implÃ©menter return, se comportant comme dans un langage impÃ©ratif - en stopant l'exÃ©cution d'une fonction :

(define (call-with-return f . args)
  (call-with-current-continuation
   ;; on utilise 'apply' pour appeler notre fonction (f)
   ;; avec la continuation + ses arguments originels grace
   ;; Ã  l'expression (cons cont args).
   ;;
   ;; Cette fonction lambda est une 'closure': elle 
   ;; capture les variables `f` et `args`
   ;; pour les rÃ©utiliser lorsqu'elle sera 
   ;; appelÃ©e par call/cc.
   (lambda (cont) (apply f (cons cont args)))))


;; On rÃ©cupÃ¨re 'return' sous forme de paramÃ¨tre
(define (add-or-leave return a b)
  (begin
    (if (= a 0)
      (return -1))
    (+ a b)))

(display (call-with-return add-or-leave 1 9))
;; -> 10
(display (call-with-return add-or-leave 0 9))
;; -> -1
(display (call-with-return add-or-leave 10 10))
;; -> 20

La diffÃ©rence est quand mÃªme "assez" majeure avec l'instruction return. Ce return ci est une fonction, qu'on peut donc Ãªtre passÃ©e en paramÃ¨tre Ã  d'autres fonctions.

ConcrÃ¨tement, c'est assez utile dans un algorithme de backtracking ou des changement de branches radicaux peuvent Ãªtre prÃ©vus. Par-dessus ces concepts (call/cc n'est pas tout seul !), on peut implÃ©menter un tas de mÃ©canismes, du systÃ¨me d'exception au coroutines.

Pour rapprocher cela Ã  Python, on pourrait se dire que yield pourrait Ãªtre une application des continuations : cette instruction permet de relÃ¢cher le flux de controle et permet l'implÃ©mentation des gÃ©nÃ©rateurs en Python.

En Scheme, yield serait une macro qui capture la continuation courante, et appelle la continuation parente avec la continuation courante en argument. Ainsi, l'appelant, ou qu'il soit, pourrait "rÃ©veiller" la fonction quand bon lui semble, en appelant la continuation obtenue en retour de la fonction. Pffiou.

En regardant du code, l'image m'est venu de certaines succession de callback en Javascript ou mÃªme des promises : on s'en rapproche - mais les continuations ne sont pas matÃ©rialisÃ©es.

Je termine avec quelques exemples de concepts que l'on peut implÃ©menter en utilisant les continuations :

  • l'instruction SWITCH

  • GOTO

  • Des GÃ©nÃ©rateurs

  • Des Green Threads

N'hÃ©sitez pas Ã  creuser si le sujet vous intÃ©resse.

entry.title: Python, Gevent and SQL-Server
entry.summary: SQL Server, python then gevent: stuff goes faster
entry.content:
Months ago, we had met requirements to migrate our main HTTP-API service to Gevent.

This service is a large, modular API system that can literally spawn APIs without downtime. We use it in many products including marketing micro-sites, client's tailored HTTP APIs, data collecting and behavior tracking. It uses Flasks as HTTP micro-framework, and dynamically loads applications (as we handle 150+ different APIs, we do not directly load all of them into memory - some of them are called once a month).

That gives us an incredible flexibility upon material resources and a very good traffic absorption, at the cost of some latency, encountered when the first HTTP requests hit an unloaded API. We don't really care about this, since we need way more availability than low latencies. Also, this allow a decreasing latency when HTTP traffic rises, because of lazy loading. Fun to see.

This whole bunch of code is proudly handled by uwsgi. Since uwsgi spawns a lot of processes per host, it can handle a lot of requests before things goes wrong.

But ... this design contained a severe mistake: what if something waits on I/O for a long time?

Like, database becoming slow after a few millions of updated rows? A remote webservice going down?

As Uwsgi spawns N processes, this number N is similar to Super Mario's amount of "lives", but Mario is your whole application, and any blocking IO operation (eg: http webservice, slow database lookups) could lower your amount of available processes/threads at a given time.

Depending on your OS, you could easily spot this... or not. Depending on how your system computes load average (does processes waiting for IO completion counts ?). Nagios will alert you. Or not.

Of course, we could spawn more processes. That's not very smart, and our servers were already overloaded. We decided to make our app gevent compliant (by avoiding potential races conditions), import gevent and monkey patch all the stuff.

After resolving a few (*^@#& pymssql/SQLServer's issues, we managed to get our app up and running on a single node of our cluster. And them - booom

Booom

Performances increased a lot... way more than we expected. We had eliminated one potential cause of unavailability, occuring when all the threads/processes are blocked, waiting for IO completion (or worst!). Gevent, allowing our processes to do "something else", while "waiting for some stuff coming from the network/disks", avoids blocking in such cases.

Seriously, it is so fast that we could have sold a server, and responses times would have been better than before the full migration.

The turquoise one is our gevented node. This is a screenshot taken after one host migration, during the beginning of the daily rush. You can clearly see that it is not even stressed, without any spikes (a spike indicates a metric computed in a thread that have blocked for several seconds).

Regarding the server itself, load average drop from 100-120 to 30.

As all the three nodes can easily absorb that traffic, latency has not increased this morning. Using gevent, do not forget the database - it can struggle upon thousand of light-threads querying results. Worst if you make a bad use of transactions (for relational only -- NoSQL will just be inconsistent) Also, it could reveal race conditions within your DB logic, so be careful with that.

Database access limitation

We have limited database access to each underlying HTTP API by using an abstraction over gevent.queue. This queue, blocking when empty, "naturally" suspends components if all of its connections are currently used.

By default, they can only fetch one database connection at one time, blocking if connection is used by another greenlet. Also, this is configurable.

Gevent could help when looking for performances, especially upon a large base of diversified code, but should be used with care :)

entry.title: python, `dis` module and bytecode
entry.content:
Diving into python - bytecode

The dis module allows python's bytecode inspection (and other funny things). As a reminder, python's code is compiled to bytecode before interpretation by CPython. This bytecode is an intermediary representation and may vary between python's implementations.

python2 store its bytecode under .pyc files, and python3 under a directory named __pycache__.

When inspected via the dis function, bytecode is pretty printed on stdout.

According to the docs, here's the columns names:

  1. the line number, for the first instruction of each line
  2. the current instruction, indicated as -->,
  3. a labelled instruction, indicated with >>,
  4. the address of the instruction,
  5. the operation code name,
  6. operation parameters, and
  7. interpretation of the parameters in parentheses.

BTW, dis.disassemble() take a <code object> as first parameter, so you'll have to compile your code before passing it.

Here's a vigorous sample:

>>> code = '''for i in range(0, 10): print(i)'''
>>> code_obj = compile(code, '<string>', 'exec')
>>> disassemble(code_obj)
  1           0 SETUP_LOOP              33 (to 36)
              3 LOAD_NAME                0 (range)
              6 LOAD_CONST               0 (0)
              9 LOAD_CONST               1 (10)
             12 CALL_FUNCTION            2 (2 positional, 0 keyword pair)
             15 GET_ITER
        >>   16 FOR_ITER                16 (to 35)
             19 STORE_NAME               1 (i)
             22 LOAD_NAME                2 (print)
             25 LOAD_NAME                1 (i)
             28 CALL_FUNCTION            1 (1 positional, 0 keyword pair)
             31 POP_TOP
             32 JUMP_ABSOLUTE           16
        >>   35 POP_BLOCK
        >>   36 LOAD_CONST               2 (None)
             39 RETURN_VALUE

it's mostly readable and clear.

Example - stupid analysis about string substitution

Stop that wrong debate about % versus .format() for string interpolation. Basically, .format is more handy in most situations.

PEP 3101

Let's compare them:

>>> code = 's = "hello %s"  %a'
>>> code_obj = compile(code, '<string>', 'exec')
>>> disassemble(code_obj)
  1           0 LOAD_CONST               0 ('hello %s')
              3 LOAD_NAME                0 (a)
              6 BINARY_MODULO
              7 STORE_NAME               1 (s)
             10 LOAD_CONST               1 (None)
             13 RETURN_VALUE
>>> code = 's = "hello {}".format(a)'
>>> code_obj = compile(code, '<string>', 'exec')
>>> disassemble(code_obj)
  1           0 LOAD_CONST               0 ('hello {}')
              3 LOAD_ATTR                0 (format)
              6 LOAD_NAME                1 (a)
              9 CALL_FUNCTION            1 (1 positional, 0 keyword pair)
             12 STORE_NAME               2 (s)
             15 LOAD_CONST               1 (None)
             18 RETURN_VALUE
>>>

We see a LOAD_ATTR then CALL_FUNCTION when .format() is called. On the other side, BINARY_MODULO does most of the job.

about timing:

>>> import timeit
>>> t = timeit.Timer(stmt='a = "test"; s = "hello %s" %a')
>>> print("%.2f usec/pass" % (1000000 * t.timeit(number=100000)/100000))
0.17 usec/pass
>>> t = timeit.Timer(stmt='a = "test"; s = "hello {}".format(a)')
>>> print("%.2f usec/pass" % (1000000 * t.timeit(number=100000)/100000))
0.33 usec/pass

% wins. Please not that it was just a simple sample, without complexity.

As .format(*args, **kwargs) is way more sophisticated than % for string interpolation, theses results are is not surprising in any way. They were just good candidates to illustrate dis and timeit python's modules.

entry.title: Emacs and HTTP(s) proxies
entry.content:
If you are using emacs and HTTP related functionalities, you could use the following snippet to reach a domain through an HTTP proxy. It works for most of the stuff I've tested so far, including the handy rest-client and package-*.

(defun unset-proxy
    (&args)
  (interactive "p")
  (setenv "http_proxy" nil)
  (setenv "https_proxy" nil)
  (setq url-proxy-services nil))


(defun set-proxy
    (&args)
  (interactive "p")
  (setq url-proxy-services
    '(("no_proxy" . "^\\(localhost\\|127.*\\)")
      ("http" . "proxy.yourdomain.com:8080")
      ("https" . "proxy.yourdomain.com:8080"))))

Just after evaluation, you can use M-x set-proxy and M-x unset-proxy.

entry.title: Rust: dÃ©couverte
entry.content:
(illustration)

Je viens de passer deux heures sur la doc de Rustlang.

Et je peux dorÃ©navant marmonner que cette techno semble dÃ©chirer. Je vais mettre les lisps de cÃ´tÃ© quelque temps et m'y pencher de plus prÃ¨s.

Les features intÃ©ressantes y sont trÃ¨s nombreuses. En plus des bÃ©nÃ©fices de la compilation et du typage, Rust dÃ©barque avec plein de fonctionnalitÃ©s assez attractives.

Et ... y'a des macros dedans

Si vous Ãªtes familiers avec les systÃ¨mes de macros des lisps, vous comprendrez aisÃ©ment l'intÃ©rÃªt des macros. Sinon, oubliez les substitutions de texte des macros en C: les macros dans Rust permettent d'Ã©tendre la syntaxe du langage. Les rÃ¨gles qui les rÃ©gissent sont donc plus exigeantes.

En pratique

En dÃ©couvrant Ã§a, j'ai voulu tester. La premiÃ¨re idÃ©e qui m'est venu Ã  l'esprit, c'est une macro permettant de composer des fonctions. ConcrÃ¨tement, Ã§a n'a pas forcÃ©ment vocation Ã  Ãªtre implÃ©mentÃ© en macro, mais pour l'exemple, Ã§a suffira.

1er jet

J'ai implÃ©mentÃ© naÃ¯vement Ã§a en utilisant des fonctions anonymes. Ce n'est surement pas idiomatique ni optimisÃ©, mais Ã§a marche.

macro_rules! compose {
    ($a:expr, $b:expr) => (|v| ( $a($b(v))));
}

Vulgairement, macro_rules! permet de dÃ©clarer une macro. Le lexÃ¨me qui le suit, compose, dÃ©signe le nom de la macro. Et ce qui suit entre { et }, c'est une expression de pattern matching appliquÃ©e au "arguments" de la macro, qui peuvent Ãªtre de toutes sortes (d'aprÃ¨s la doc)

* ident: an identifier. Examples: x; foo.
* path: a qualified name. Example: T::SpecialA.
* expr: an expression. Examples: 2 + 2; if true { 1 } else { 2 }; f(42).
* ty: a type. Examples: i32; Vec<(char, String)>; &T.
* pat: a pattern. Examples: Some(t); (17, 'a'); _.
* stmt: a single statement. Example: let x = 3.
* block: a brace-delimited sequence of statements. Example: { log(error, "hi"); return 12; }.
* item: an item. Examples: fn foo() { }; struct Bar;.
* meta: a "meta item", as found in attributes. Example: cfg(target_os = "windows").
* tt: a single token tree.

Revenons Ã  compose. Effectivement, Ã§a fonctionne :

fn main() {
    let f = |x:u32|(x + 1);
    let g = |x:u32|(x + 5);
    let h = compose!(f, g);
    println!("h(4)={}", h(4));
}

$ rustc utils.rs && ./utils
$ h(4)=10

Ã€ premiÃ¨re vue, Ã§a marche, comme ((4 + 1) + 5) = 10 Et si on regardait Ã  quoi ressemblait la macro aprÃ¨s expansion ? Par exemple, Clojure permet de voir Ã  quoi ressemble une macro aprÃ¨s expansion avec la macro macroexpand. Rust Ã©tant un langage compilÃ©, c'est vers le compilateur qu'il faut se tourner :

$ rustc -Z unstable-options --pretty expanded utils.rs
[...]

    let f = |x: u32| (x + 1);
    let g = |x: u32| (x + 5);
    let h = |v| (f(g(v)));
[...]
}

La dÃ©claration ci-dessous nous intÃ©resse plus particuliÃ¨rement :

c'est donc plus ou moins ce qu'on voulait, avec la vÃ©rification des types en prime. En effet, si on dÃ©clare la fonction g tel que let g = |x:u64|(x + 5.5);, le compilateur nous explique calmement que :

error: mismatched types:
 expected `u32`,
    found `u64` [E0308]
[...] note: in this expansion of compose!

En rÃ©sumÃ©, malgrÃ¨s une faible adoption (mÃªme si Firefox arrive avec du Rust dedans en aoÃ»t) et assez peu de hype autour du projet, je pense que Rust peut trouver sa place. J'y trouve plusieurs idÃ©es intÃ©ressantes.

entry.title: SSH Honey pot avec python et paramiko
entry.content:
Ces derniers temps, je me suis un peu interessÃ© Ã  la librairie paramiko qui permet d'abstraire le protocole SSH avec python. J'en ai profitÃ© pour rÃ©aliser un petit honeypot ssh histoire d'exporer les possibilitÃ©s de cette libraire.

Serveur - paramiko.ServerInterface

import paramiko

paramiko.util.log_to_file('demo_server.log')
host_key = paramiko.RSAKey(filename='test_rsa.key')

# implÃ©mentation des diffÃ©rentes mÃ©thodes qui vont nous servir.
# On a pas besoin de grand chose, Ã©tant donnÃ© que l'on veut juste
# rÃ©cupÃ©rer les identifiants et non Ã©tablir une vraie connexion SSH.

class Server (paramiko.ServerInterface):
    """Paramiko powered SSH Server - basic implementation"""

    def check_auth_password(self, username, password):
        print("{}:{}".format(username, password))
        return paramiko.AUTH_FAILED

    def get_allowed_auths(self, username):
        """Return a comma separated list of
        valid auth."""
        return 'password'

VoilÃ , Ã§a ne fait pas beaucoup de code. On a redÃ©fini quelques mÃ©thodes de paramiko.ServerInterface :

get_allowed_auths :

D'aprÃ¨s la doc:

get_allowed_auths(username)
Return a list of authentication methods supported by the server. This list is sent to clients attempting to authenticate, to inform them of authentication methods that might be successful.

The â€œlistâ€ is actually a string of comma-separated names of types of authentication. Possible values are "password", "publickey", and "none".

The default implementation always returns "password".

cette fonction permet de prÃ©ciser au client par quel(s) moyen(s) il peut se connecter Ã  ce serveur SSH.

check_auth_password :

Egalement, d'aprÃ¨s la doc:

check_auth_password(username, password)
Determine if a given username and password supplied by the client is acceptable for use in authentication.

Return AUTH_FAILED if the password is not accepted, AUTH_SUCCESSFUL if the password is accepted and completes the authentication, or AUTH_PARTIALLY_SUCCESSFUL if your authentication is stateful, and this key is accepted for authentication, but more authentication is required. (In this latter case, get_allowed_auths will be called to report to the client what options it has for continuing the authentication.)

The default implementation always returns AUTH_FAILED.

Cette fonction s'occupe donc de vÃ©rifier l'authenticitÃ© du mot de passe et du nom d'utilisateur.

Accepter des connexions entrantes:

Plus commode, on va crÃ©er une socket et la binder sur le port voulu.

import socket
import sys

try:
    sock = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)
    sock.setsockopt(socket.SOL_SOCKET, socket.SO_REUSEADDR, 1)
    sock.bind(('', 1025))
except Exception as e:

    sys.exit(1)

    client, addr = sock.accept()

    sys.exit(1)

C'est pas super joli, ni maintenable (le code est Ã  l'arrache dans l'espace global), mais Ã§a devrait faire l'affaire. Y'a plus qu'Ã  faire quelque chose de client, addr, les donner Ã  notre serveur pour qu'il s'occupe de l'intÃ©raction SSH. Ce bout de code bloque Ã  la ligne client, addr = sock.accept(). Si l'execution va plus loin que block except, c'est qu'on a un client connectÃ©.

# on instancie un nouveau Transport avec notre socket client.
t = paramiko.Transport(client)

t.add_server_key(host_key)
server = Server()

    t.start_server(server=server)

# on n'arrivera jamais jusqu'ici.

Plus qu'Ã  tester:

Listening for connection ...
root:toto
root:tutu
root:titi

Depuis un autre terminal:

root@localhost's password:
Permission denied, please try again.
root@localhost's password:
Permission denied (password).

Et voilÃ . Cette implÃ©mentation reste assez minimaliste, et je ne pense pas que cette base de code puisse rÃ©ellement Ãªtre utilisÃ©e pour un honey pot (du moins, sans quelques ajouts.) Mais Ã§a illustre bien l'approche de paramiko. Prochaine Ã©tape, faire en sorte que le serveur puisse gÃ©rer plusieurs connexions simutanÃ©es (asyncIO ?)

IntÃ©gralitÃ© du code source d'exemple:

#!/usr/bin/env python


import socket
import sys
import paramiko

# logging

paramiko.util.log_to_file('demo_server.log')

host_key = paramiko.RSAKey(filename='test_rsa.key')

class Server (paramiko.ServerInterface):
    """Paramiko powered SSH Server - basic implementation"""
